intro: Blakea calcarata, commonly known as the rock bladder, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its thick, succulent stems and leaves that are often covered in a waxy coating, helping it retain moisture in its arid habitat. Its flowers are typically yellow or orange, with five petals and a prominent central stamen. Blakea calcarata is often grown as an ornamental plant due to its unique appearance and ability to thrive in well-drained soil.
